awd_titl_txt: AGS-PRF: Experimentally Determined Volatility of Secondary Organic Aerosol Formed Through Aqueous Oxidation
awd_abstract_narration:
Secondary organic aerosols (SOA) are small particles produced by the oxidation of organic gases emitted by forests, fossil fuel combustion and fires. Complex chemical processes that are not well represented in climate models and are a source of large uncertainties in climate assessments produce sOAs. In particular the oxidation of organic gases by water in cloud drops is recognized to be important but there are limited studies to represent the processes that produce the particles and their properties. The proposed work will measure and quantify the persistence of these aqueous SOA particles by measuring their volatility in the laboratory and their inclusion in climate models will enable more robust assessments. 

In order to constrain aqueous SOA (aqSOA) production mechanism this research would experimentally quantify the volatility of aqSOA compounds that determine the low volatility fraction that survive evaporation and scavenging to effect global climate. The goal is to probe the fundamental relationship between the precursor molecular properties and aqSOA volatility. The laboratory studies will elucidate aqSOA-volatility relationships from (1) methylglyoxal, pyruvic acid, and methyl-vinyl ketone oxidation, (2) oxidation products in precipitation samples and (3) dried organic aerosol oxidation. The oxidation will be performed by hydroxyl radicals produced from hydrogen peroxide photolysis in a batch reactor, the mixtures will be aerosolized with a vibration orifice aerosol generator then evaporated in a flow tube and finally detected by an optical particle counter. Polarity-resolved volatility distributions will be measured using elution and ion chromatography. The results will elucidate the fundamental volatility properties of aqSOA to understand how they effect past, present and future climate.

por.por_cntn:
Air pollution and climate change are the primary threat to global health in 2019 (World Health Organization, 2019). Aerosols affect climate by regulating the distribution of water vapor as it condenses to form clouds. The role of aerosols in climate is known to be substantial, yet it remains the most uncertain element in climate projections. Aerosols reduce the life expectancy of up to 7 billion people worldwide through an increase in cardiovascular and respiratory diseases. This project investigates routes to formation of new particulate matter through multiphase reactions facilitated by liquid water in the atmosphere.

Multiphase reactions in humidified aerosols and fogs are a key step in the conversion of biogenic volatile organic compounds (BVOCs) to particulate mass. Isoprene is the dominant BVOC emitted into the atmosphere, but the gas-phase oxidation of isoprene does not directly result in aerosol. Instead, water-soluble gases produced in photochemical breakdown of isoprene and other BVOCs can contribute to aerosol mass by partitioning into existing particles and undergoing water-mediated reactions, forming less volatile compounds. Unknown product volatility and the aerosol yield of these multiphase reactions has been highlighted as a major deficiency in air quality and climate models. This project explored reaction mechanisms, stereochemistry, and volatility of isoprene-derived compounds reacting in aqueous systems.

We investigated multiphase reactions of pyruvic acid, an abundant water-soluble gas produced though photooxidation of isoprene. Pyruvic acid is highly volatile but can react in water to form less volatile compounds. We demonstrated that various reaction pathways render pyruvic acid less volatile. OH-radical initiated photochemistry results in less volatile carboxylic acids and keto-acids. We show excellent agreement between the reaction mechanism and volatility of reacted mixtures. Evaporation experiments closely mimicking cloud droplets were performed and show dimerization of pyruvic acid as another mechanism by which this compound becomes less volatile. Independent experiments conducted at the University of Bristol (Bristol, UK) confirmed the low-volatility product formation in solution upon evaporation. We demonstrated the volumetric yield of dimerization of pyruvic acid at a range of atmospheric temperatures (10–25°C) and relevant solution strengths (aerosol, fog, and cloud water concentrations). This work advances atmospheric chemistry by demonstrating a route to lower volatility products from a previously unexplored system, building knowledge of reactions of pyruvic acid and other analogous carbonyls in the atmosphere.

We developed a multicomponent evaporation model incorporating heat and mass transport equations and excess energy of mixing. This model continues to impact atmospheric chemistry by informing investigations of reactions occurring in highly dynamic aerosols with evaporating components. This project also impacts the field of environmental health because the evaporation model developed here is being incorporated into the study of the gas/particle partitioning of e-cigarette aerosols.

We investigated reactions of isoprene-derived epoxydiols (IEPOX) in acidified aqueous solutions. Atmospheric oxidation of isoprene yields large quantities of IEPOX in regions with low NOx concentrations, and multiphase reactions of IEPOX on sulfate aerosols can contribute substantially to the organic fraction of fine aerosol. In aqueous aerosols, acid-catalyzed ring-opening reactions of IEPOX followed by nucleophilic addition of inorganic sulfate or water results in organosulfates and 2-methyltetrols, respectively. We demonstrate that the reaction favors the formation of 2-methyltetrols under fog-relevant conditions. Furthermore, trans-β-IEPOX and cis-β-IEPOX isomers were found to produce distinct organosulfate isomers. We showed that the acid-catalyzed rate constant for the ring-opening reaction of the IEPOX at dilute conditions is higher than that reported for aerosol conditions. By separating tertiary and secondary isomers of the organosulfate product, we probed the stereochemistry of the ring opening. Formation of secondary organosulfates was enhanced over the tertiary isomer under fog-relevant pH. Because secondary organosulfates are more stable in the atmosphere than the tertiary isomer, this implies that the reaction of IEPOX in cloud water, though slower, results in enhanced stability of organosulfates relative to those formed in aerosols. This work advances atmospheric chemistry by providing insight into reactions of IEPOX in water and sheds light on stereoisomers of IEPOX-derived organosulfates detected in the atmosphere.

This project had a positive impact on society by supporting the convergence of participants of local, national, and international origin. The project contributed to full participation of women in STEM by supporting the Fellow and through her service as a resource and informal mentor for a diverse group within the hosting laboratories. The Fellow served as the sole PI, designing and conducting research under mentorship of Profs. Barbara Turpin and Jason Surratt. Additional insight and experimental methods were incorporated through collaboration with Profs. Jonathan Reid (University of Bristol, UK) and Faye McNeill (Columbia University). Public engagement in science and technology in North Carolina was increased through an outreach collaboration with Swain County Cooperative Extension 4-H Club. In 2019 the Fellow accepted the CIBA/YCC Young Scientist Travel Award to present this project at the American Chemical Society 2019 Fall Meeting.
